comment.author: 9550356@N02
comment._content: Very nice! When this pic was tooked?

comment.author: 25053835@N03
comment._content: We don’t know the date the picture was taken.  The negative/photograph is not dated and we haven’t been able to identify the sculpted bust shown in the photograph.  We can only guess the age of the artist in the photograph.  The artist’s life spanned almost an entire century, but her artistic career blossomed starting in early mid-life.  Born in Mooresville, North Carolina, she arrived in New York City during the burgeoning of African American artistic expression, was a member of the Harlem Artists Guild and involved with the Harlem Works Progress Administration (WPA) project.  In the late 1930s, she studied in France, Germany and Austria and upon return to the United States, received numerous portrait commissions.  In 1940, she opened the Selma Burke School of Sculpture and at age 41 earned her M.F.A. from Columbia University.

comment.author: 40555891@N08
comment._content: The sculpted bust appears to be a self-portrait since the lips, eyes, ears and hair are a very close match to the artist.

comment.author: 94118790@N04
comment._content:
What a lovely thing to discover, I am. Lee rating International Women's Day!

I think Ms. Selma Burke, does make women all over the world proud!

To be a sculptor, who in her lifetime was acclaimed, and innovated Preisent Franklin Delano Roosevelt likes on the dime, that we keep today!

comment.author: 94118790@N04
comment._content:
I am celebrating International Women's Day!  I am inspired, and very elated to discover the bit of artistic history, and again proud to be a women, and thank god, for all of our accomplishments.

Thank you, Flickr
